sections.heading: Discussions
sections.text: A major challenge in the analysis of words in Chinese poetry is word segmentation. Traditional experience indicates that most words in poetry consist of one or two characters 25. Based on this heuristics, we can algorithmically analyze the corpora with about 4.9 million characters. To truly understand and appreciate poetry, one should not read it literally. Metaphor recognition can be crucial to reveal the true intentions of poets. Observations resulting from the quantitative analysis of QTS and QSC open windows to promising research opportunities about QTS, QSC and their transition. Besides colors, concepts about astronomical objects, floral beings, meteorological phenomena, and geographical landmarks are important participants in poetry. Innovative colorations of them paint impressive images in the minds of readers. Good computer tools can help researchers explore the world of poets more efficiently.

metadata.abstractText: Tang (618-907 AD) and Song (960-1279) dynasties are two very important periods in the development of Chinese literary. The majority forms of the poetry in Tang and Song were Shi (詩) and Ci (詞), respectively. Tang Shi and Song Ci established crucial foundations of the Chinese literature, and their influences in both literary works and daily lives of the Chinese communities last until today. Recognizing the importance of Tang Shi, a Chinese emperor of the Qing dynasty (1644-1912), Kangxi, ordered to compile a collection of Tang poems, Quan-Tang-Shi (QTS, 全唐詩). QTS contains nearly 50 thousand works of about 2200 poets. A similar effort for compiling a collection of Song Ci from the private sector began in the Ming dynasty (1368-1644), and achieved in a collection called Quan-Song-Ci (QSC, 全宋詞) in the early Republican period of China (ca. 1937). QSC contains around 20 thousand works of about 1330 poets. The exact statistics about QTS and QSC may vary slightly depending on the sources. In the past more than a thousand years, literary and linguistic researchers have had done a myriad of research about the poetry of the Tang and Song dynasties. Hence, it is beyond our capacity and not our objective to review the literature in this abstract. Traditional researchers studied and compared poetic works that were produced by different authors and in different time periods to produce insightful and invaluable analyses and commentaries. Most of the time, the researchers focused on the poems of selected poets. Even when computing supports become available, studying poems of specific poets is still an important and popular type of research in poetry. Software tools facilitate the analysis of poetry from a panoramic perspective, and may lead to applications that would be very challenging in the past.
